item.title: Formalising Classification Schema
item.description: I’m temporarily staying near a state park and have had a lot of opportunity to do my favourite thing–extended walks in nature where I can go down deep holes I‚Äôd typically consider best left to rabbits with pocket watches. Today, my errant mind decided it was time to formalise and classify different types of nuance (because nothing is more nuanced than a formal classification schema). I think that one of the most important skills for thinking fairly and accurately is considering nuance: resisting binary dichotomies on complex and important topics.

item.title: Travel Superpowers
item.description: (Just repaired my old laptop, and I’m going through my diary entries. I’m so glad they were recoverable. Here’s one of my (somewhat emotional) retrospectives that I had started a few months ago and finished just now.) There was some thread online talking about “travel superpowers”, such as the ability to fall asleep easily in transit, to negotiate with pedlars, or to find cheap accommodation. My answer is something I inherited from my dad–blithe fearlessness.

item.title: Phone-y Bologna
item.description: Me: “Where does all my time go? How am I supposed to get anything done? When’s the last time I even ate?” Also Me: Spends an hour on the phone with his friend in India Spends fourty-five minutes on the phone with his friend living three blocks away Spends an hour and a half on the phone with his best friend’s mom Spends an hour and a half on the phone with his former boss Spends two hours on the phone talking to his sister’s mother-in-law Continues to scroll his contact list and try calling numbers who probably aren’t picking up because they know there’s no such thing as a quick ten-minute ‘check-in’ with him This is literally how long I spent on the phone today guys, I have the timestamps

item.title: Boxer Shorts
item.description: Very random fun fact–in India, it is customary for men to wear a second pair of underwear underneath their boxers. Which turns them into acceptable loungewear and marginally acceptable attire for a very casual motorcycle ride down to the market.

item.title: True Love's Kiss
item.description: There is a cruelty to the fairy godmothers, though they don’t mean it that way; there is an inhumanity to their love of lessons and surprise twists. If a man falls ill of a deadly sickness, his fairy godmother cannot simply alleviate his suffering and send him on his way. Oh, she has the power to just heal him, to be certain. She has the power to transform mice into horses, if she pleases.

item.title: Gora Problems
item.description: Had an exceptionally good day in Indore, topped by a conversation with a stand-up comedian named Div, who was curious about my perception of India. (I asked him if he had more than fifteen minutes for me to adequately respond to that, and he pointed out that, if I hadn’t noticed, we were both sitting alone in a restaurant on a Friday night eating “fucking poha”.) At some point, I mentioned that on the way there, the auto driver had stopped and introduced me to two of his friends.

item.title: Maratha Blues
item.description: #1 on the list of things I don’t appreciate about Maharastra: How I kind of like the taste of raw onions after living here. This is NOT good for your love lives, guys, just remember that.

item.title: Isaac's Checklist For Hard-Balling Autowallas...
item.description: Isaac’s Checklist For Hard-Balling Autowallas That Start Out The Negotiation At 3.5x The Amount You Know It Actually Should Cost To Get To Your Destination: 1.) An amused smile and a “Baaaaaaaaapre.” The longer and more drawn out, the better–this is a sign of virility in the Maratha culture. Men often sit in a circle and contest each other with how long they can draw out their “bapre"s. Having asserted your masculinity, offer the fair price times 1.

item.title: Do-uble Entendre
item.description: I was on an online forum discussing some of India’s greatest unsolved mysteries, and someone wrote “One of the unsolved mysteries is that someone stole my self esteem and I can’t get it back.” Until I read someone’s response (“Bhai Tinder uninstall kar do, self respect wapas aa jayegi”), I somehow parsed the poster as saying that his car (Maruti Esteem) was stolen. I should have been tipped off by the idea that someone had stolen that model of car, if nothing else.

item.title: Reunion
Bajaranji Bakvaas
Cultural Exchange
Mysterious Ways
item.description: Brains work in, uh, mysterious ways. Today, I observed the weirdest instance of mine getting its “wires crossed”. In lieu of change, a salesclerk gave me a couple pieces of expresso candy. My intention afterwards was to eat a piece of candy and simultaneously start a work task. I sat down and popped the candy in my mouth, all according to plan. But suddenly, I felt a surge of alarm, convinced for a split-second that I had somehow eaten the task I was intending to complete.

item.title: Dostana Chaiye?
Meh Americano Samajatha Hoon
Pani Hai
item.description: On my daily commute home, I was carrying some rum to share for a birthday party in our P.G. After my bag went through the scanner at the metro station and I retrieved it, the female guard ran after me and indicated I needed to talk to the analyst about something he saw on the scanner. Analyst: “Water bottle?” Isaac: “Nei nei. Um…” (Unzips bag to show contents) Analyst (smiling as he examines the rum bottle): “Water bottle hai.

item.title: Unwraveling the Indian Head Bobble
item.description: After much time and study, I finally cracked the mystery of the Indian Head-Bobble. All people with association to Indian culture will surely know about the Indian head-bobble. More common in the south than the north, it’s a curious side-to-side motion, something like shaking your head but around the x-axis. When it actually applies, however, is a mystery even few natives can explain. When I came to India the first time, I first thought it was a somehow deferential way of saying “I’m neither confirming nor denying your assumption”, because I saw a teenager use it instead of actually answering when questioned about his activities.

item.title: Customer Service
item.description: One of the many idiosyncrasies of India is its customer service. On one hand, you have the infamous call centers that require 35 digit confirmation numbers (or God help you) and that can’t ever seem to use common sense if it requires going off-script. Banks where you literally have to negotiate to open a checking account, or who will send you to three different branches to avoid dealing with you. Thoroughly spiteful building managers who turn off the elevator when guests are over.

item.description: I recently moved into a P.G. item.title: The Gunner
item.description: (Today we got back our midterms in my computer science-oriented Probability and Statistics course. The TA told us the highest score was a 48 (out of fifty) and the lowest was in the tens but the average was somewhere in the thirties. The grade would be curved. Computer science is a discipline full of chest-beating, maybe due to being skewed male and rife with impostor syndrome. One guy in particular is a good example–he complained loudly about covering the material in India during his tenth grade year, he has a tendency to blurt out the answer preemptively when the professor is guiding the class on a problem, and he frequently laughs when other students ask a question he feels is obvious (and takes it on himself to explain the answer as condescendingly as humanly possible).

item.title: A Five Minute Deconstruction of Free Will
item.description: (This way-too-long, way-too-digressive response was written for a discussion about the nature of poverty and whether or not it’s a choice. There’s a much easier argument to be made that poverty isn’t much of a choice in most cases without delving into the philosophical topic of free will, but I’m doing this for free, so this is what you get.) There are a number of approaches you can take to dissolve the concept of free will, and/or the concept of personal responsibility.

item.title: Faux Maturity
item.description: Symptoms of faux maturity: Avoiding things you’d find fun because they are not what an “adult” does. (E.g. Dyeing your hair purple, playing video games.) Doing things you hate because they ARE what an “adult” does. (Buying a house, tending to a lawn, smoking, drinking coffee or alcohol.) Shaming or thinking less of people for doing harmless but weird or non-age-typical things. (Scoffing at someone for watching cartoons or putting M&Ms on their pizza.

item.title: Algorithmic Bias in Machine Learning
item.description: A few days back I read this article about algorithmic bias. Its argument as far as I can tell is as follows: When people complain about algorithms being biased (e.g. racially), they aren’t understanding how algorithms work. The algorithms are just performing statistics. The same statistics that reliably decide whether an email is spam or not spam, the same statistics that biologists use to study populations. Race factually correlates with things like the probability of a criminal reoffending, and all the algorithms are doing is correctly calculating the probability that a given criminal is going to reoffend based on the available data.

item.title: Anthropological Anxiety
item.description: Isaac’s mandatory mental checklist whilst hanging out with his (majority desi / south asian) friends: Make an extremely convoluted conclusion about desi culture. What observations cause you to draw this conclusion? What assumptions are supporting the way you notice and interpret those actions? In what scenarios could those assumptions possibly be legitimate or illegitimate, and is that even a clearly defined boundary? Am I overthinking this? I‚Äôm overthinking this. This is not how a normal person hangs out with their friends.

Me: (spends time doing simple thing) Me: WAIT AHHHHH Me: NO THIS DOES NOT WORK WHY DID I NOT TRUST 2016 ME WHO OBVIOUSLY THOUGHT THIS THROUGH DAMN IT

item.title: It's called shoestring travelling, and there's a SUBREDDIT, thank you
item.description: Isaac [talking to another student worker]: “It’s completely possible to travel in India for less than $200 a month. You just have to be willing to give up all pretense of safety and comfort. Mostly, just be gregarious with people you meet in general and even on the street–they’ll invite you to stay with them, and your travels will totally be enriched.” Boss (exasperated, horrified): “Isaac, where are your parents?”

item.title: Bakari Bakvaas
Ramayario
item.description: It’s absolutely the last thing on my priority list right now, but it occurred to me that it would be a lot of fun to make a Ramayana version of the Mario games where Mario is Rama, Sita is Peach, Donkey Kong is Hanuman, and Bowser is Ravana.

item.title: CSI: Applied Statistics
item.description: It’s been a notion in my mind for a long time–that the ‘unsexy’ engineering jobs save more lives than firefighters and first-responders do, by building buildings, cars, and systems (including the equipment firefighters use) to be safe and functional. (So if you want to do something good for the world with you career, being a firefighter works, but keep in mind that people don’t celebrate the hard-working engineers whenever a bridge doesn’t fall down or when their cell works to call 911 in the first place.

item.title: Monkey Business
item.description: (While hiking in a state park with a friend recently from Mumbai) Friend: “Isaac, you should ask one of us to watch of your bag while you’re climbing.” Isaac: “I feel pretty safe. Are you worried about something in particular?” Friend: “Monkeys could get into it and mess with your stuff. I’ve seen that happen so many times.” Isaac: “There aren’t any monkeys in America.” Friend suspiciously: “…Sure.”

item.title: Moral Nuance in Racial Discourse
item.description: Thought experiment time! Gina is an upper-middle-class woman who works as a professor in a university in inner-city Detroit. She idealistically started her kid in an inner-city school, because she believed the ‘white flight’ from American cities was a big contributor to cycle of poverty. One day, her child comes home with a gash on her temple because she got in the way of some older kids fighting; a gang thing, the school administration tells her.

item.title: World's #1 Occasional Dictator
item.description: Testing my friends hypothesis, “You can’t annoy me with talks about politics.” (In the tradition of trolling the other while they are lifting weights.) TEST ONE: Isaac: “Gandhi did a creepy chastity experiment with his teenaged nieces.” Friend: “I know that.” TEST TWO: Isaac: “Modi acted really suspiciously during the Gujarati riots.” Friend: Grunts non-commitadly TEST THREE: Isaac: “The economic boom in India is due mainly to low oil prices, and the BJP is just taking credit for that without instituting the unpopular sweeping changes the economy really needs.

item.title: The more you know...
Labour Camp
item.description: Isaac’s professor: “[Taking summer calculus] will probably be the hardest thing you ever do in college. You must study for four to five hours a day. If any of you have full-time jobs, I suggest you take leave from them. This class is like labor camp.” Isaac: smiles unwillingly Isaac’s professor: looks at Isaac “I see you are laughing. But I am Russian. I know what labor camp is. Isaac: REALLY smiling now

item.title: Conversations With Missionaries
item.description: So today I sat down with a couple of missionaries (who often target me I think because I’m often alone and sitting outside, reading.) I generally enjoy such conversations, because missionaries are a friendly bunch and I’ve spent way more time than your average person thinking about religion. But during such conversations, there are some cultural mistakes that happen with such regularity, and I feel like we spend most of the conversation correcting those rather than actually getting to the meat of anything.
